title: 4) EDA II
text:
This module involves a first exploratory analysis.
The idea is to have a first contact with the data.
# recommended packages
library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)
library(viridis)

title: 4) EDA II
text:
What to Analyze?
Here are some EDA ideas.

Tile Graph
Tile Graph of Year and Month

# without viridis color palette
crashes |> 
  count(ACCIDENT_YEAR, MONTH, name = "count") |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = ACCIDENT_YEAR, y = MONTH)) +
  geom_tile(aes(fill = count), linewidth = 0.5, color = "white") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 2014:2023) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = 1:12)


# with viridis color palette
crashes |> 
  count(ACCIDENT_YEAR, MONTH, name = "count") |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = ACCIDENT_YEAR, y = MONTH)) +
  geom_tile(aes(fill = count), linewidth = 0.5, color = "white") +
  scale_fill_viridis() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 2014:2023) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = 1:12)



More Tile Graphs

Month (x-axis) & Day of week (y-axis), for all years
Month (x-axis) & Day of week (y-axis), for a given year
Month (x-axis) & Day of week (y-axis), faceting by year
Week (x-axis) & Day of week (y-axis)



Types of Collision

# most common type of collision
crashes |> 
  count(TYPE_OF_COLLISION, name = "count", sort = TRUE)


# most common type of collision
crashes |> 
  count(TYPE_OF_COLLISION, name = "count", sort = TRUE) |> 
  ggplot(aes(y = reorder(TYPE_OF_COLLISION, count), x = count)) +
  geom_col() +
  labs(title = "Number of crashes (2014-2023)",
       y = "Type of crash")



Type of collision per year

crashes |> 
  count(ACCIDENT_YEAR, TYPE_OF_COLLISION, name = "count") |> 


# normalized bar chart (Year, type of crash)
crashes |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = ACCIDENT_YEAR, fill = TYPE_OF_COLLISION)) +
  geom_bar(position = "fill")


# bar chart (Year, type of crash)
crashes |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = ACCIDENT_YEAR, fill = TYPE_OF_COLLISION)) +
  geom_bar()


# timeline (type of crash per year)
crashes |> 
  count(ACCIDENT_YEAR, TYPE_OF_COLLISION, name = "count") |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = ACCIDENT_YEAR, y = count, color = TYPE_OF_COLLISION)) +
  geom_line()



Other ideas

Most Common Type of Collision per Month
Most Common Type of Collision per Hour
Most Common Type of Collision per Hour and Day
Most Common Type of Collision per County
Most Common Type of Collision in a given City

title: 8) Quarto Websites II
text: In this module we continue describing more elements and uses of Quarto websites.

title: 8) Quarto Websites II
text:
Creating a Personal Website
Reminder: documentation about Quarto Websites is available in the followin link
https://quarto.org/docs/websites/
I want authors to have their own personal website. One option to have this type of website is by using a Quarto Website. To be more precise: it would be nice to have a so-called personal landing page.

Content
The content of a personal website does not have to be extensive. In fact, it can be composed by a top navigation (navbar) menu with tabs:

Home
Resume
About


Home
This is the landing page. It is a welcome page to tell the audience who you are, and what you do. I recommend using this page as the gallery to your personal portfolio of projects or creations.


Resume
You can have a dedicated tab for your resume, and possibly link it to your LinkedIn profile.


About
This is a customary element of personal websites, in which you have a “Bio” page or more information about your career, interests, hobbies, etc.

title: 8) Quarto Websites II
text:
Activities

Create a Quarto Website for your Personal Website
Show dummy version
Add a photo to your landing page
List some projects or ideas for your portfolio
Draft your resume in the Resume page
Draft content for your About page

Example of _quarto.yaml config file for a personal website:
project:
  type: website

website:
  title: "First Last"
  navbar:
    left:
      - href: index.qmd
        text: Home
      - about.qmd
      - resume.qmd

format:
  html:
    theme: zephyr
    fontsize: 1em
    css: styles.css
    toc: true
Sample mock-up personal website:

Demo: https://dataviz.quarto.pub/me/
Code: https://github.com/gastonstat/quarto-pub-me/tree/main

title: 1) Crash Data
text: In this module we introduce the data for the project.

title: 1) Crash Data
text:
Data: California Crash Data (2014-2023)
The source of the data for this assignment is the Statewide Integrated Traffic Records System (SWITRS) which consists of data collected and maintained by the California Highway Patrol (CHP).
Special thanks go to Amalia Stahl—from the Safe Transportation Research and Education Center (SafeTREC) at UC Berkeley—who provided the CSV files for this project.

Data File
The data is available in CSV format: crashes_2014_2023.csv
See Box folder.




Data Documentation
Below is the list of variables (i.e. fields, attributes) in the CSV file.

CASE_ID:

Meaning: Case Id
Description: The unique identifier of the crash case 

ACCIDENT_YEAR:

Meaning: Crash Year
Description: The year when the crash occurred
Values: 2014 to 2023 

COLLISION_DATE:

Meaning: Crash Date
Description: The date when the crash occurred (YYYYMMDD) 

COLLISION_TIME:

Meaning: Crash Time
Description: The time when the crash occurred in 24 hour military time 

DAY_OF_WEEK:

Meaning: Day of Week
Description: The code for the day of the week when the crash occurred
Values:

1 - Monday
2 - Tuesday
3 - Wednesday
…
7 - Sunday 


WEATHER_1:

Meaning: Weather 1
Description: Weather condition at the time of the crash
Values:

Clear
Cloudy
Raining
Snowing
Fog
Other
Wind
Unknown 


WEATHER_2:

Meaning: Weather 2
Description: Additional weather condition at the time of the crash
Values: Same as Weather 1 above 

STATE_HWY_IND:

Meaning: State Highway Indicator
Description: A flag to indicate whether the crash is on or near a state highway.
Values:

Yes
No
Unknown 


COLLISION_SEVERITY

Meaning: Crash severity
Description: The worst injury suffered by any victim in the crash
Values:

Fatal injury
Severe injury
Minor injury
Possible injury
No injury 


NUMBER_KILLED

Meaning: Killed Victims
Description: Number of killed victims
Values: 0 to N for each crash 

NUMBER_INJURED

Meaning: Injured Victims
Description: Number of injured victims
Values: 0 to N for each crash 

PARTY_COUNT

Meaning: Party count
Description: Number of parties involved in the crash. Note: a vehicle counts as one party regardless of the number of occupants.
Values: 1 to N for each crash 

PCF_VIOL_CATEGORY:

Meaning: PCF Violation Category
Description: A value computed from the law section that was given as the primary cause of the crash
Values:

DUI.
Impeding traffic.
Unsafe speed.
Following too closely.
Wrong side of road.
Improper passing.
Unsafe lane change.
Improper turning.
Automobile right of way.
Pedestrian right of way.
Pedestrian violation.
Traffic signals and signs.
Hazardous parking.
Lights.
Brakes.
Other equipment.
Other hazardous violation.
Other than driver.
Unsafe starting or backing.
Other improper driving.
Pedestrian DUI.
Fell asleep.
Unknown. 


TYPE_OF_COLLISION:

Meaning: Type of crash
Description: The general type of crash as determined by the first injury or damage-causing event.
Values:

Head-on
Sideswipe
Rear End
Broadside
Hit object
Overturned
Vehicle/pedestrian
Other
Unknown 


ROAD_SURFACE:

Meaning: Road surface
Description: Roadway surface condition at the time of the crash in the traffic lane(s) involved.
Values:

Dry
Wey
Snowy or icy
Slippery (muddy, oily)
Unknown 


ROAD_COND_1:

Meaning: Road condition 1
Description: Roadway condition at the time of the crash in the traffic lane(s) involved.
Values:

Holes, deep ruts
Loose material on roadway
Obstruction on roadway
Construction or repair zone
Reduced roadway width
Flooded
Other
No unusual condition
Unknown 


ROAD_COND_2:

Meaning: Road condition 2
Description: Roadway condition at the time of the crash in the traffic lane(s) involved.
Values: Same as road condition 1 above 

LIGHTING:

Meaning: Lighting
Description: Lighting conditions at the crash location and the time of the crash.
Values:

Daylight
Dusk-dawn
Dark street lights
Dark no street lights
Dark street lights not working
Unknown 


PEDESTRIAN_ACCIDENT:

Meaning: Pedestrian crash
Description: Indicates whether the crash involved a pedestrian
Values:

Yes
No 


BICYCLE_ACCIDENT:

Meaning: Bicycle crash
Description: Indicates whether the crash involved a bicycle
Values:

Yes
No 


MOTORCYCLE_ACCIDENT:

Meaning: Motorcycle crash
Description: Indicates whether the crash involved a motorcycle
Values:

Yes
No 


TRUCK_ACCIDENT:

Meaning: Truck crash
Description: Indicates whether the crash involved a big truck
Values:

Yes
No 


NOT_PRIVATE_PROPERTY:

Meaning: Not Private property
Description: Indicates whether the crash did not occur on private property
Values:

Yes
No 


ALCOHOL_INVOLVED:

Meaning: Alcohol involved
Description: Indicates whether the crash involved a party that had been drinking. Note: a passenger does not count as a party.
Values:

Yes
No 


COUNTY:

Meaning: County
Description: County where the crash occurred. 

CITY:

Meaning: City
Description: City where the crash occurred.
Values: Various cities are simply labeled as “Unincorporated” 

POINT_X:

Meaning: X coordinate location
Description: The longitude of the geocoded location; uses the World Geodetic System from 1984 (WGS84) 

POINT_Y:

Meaning: Y coordinate location
Description: The latitude of the geocoded location; uses the World Geodetic System from 1984 (WGS84)






File Structure
The following diagram depicts a sample file structure for how we could organize the data files of this project:
california-crashes/
    data/
        crashes_2014_2023.csv
        data-preparation.R
        ...
    analysis/
        eda-doc1.qmd
        eda-doc2.qmd
        ...




Import CSV
To import the CSV file we can use read_csv()
library(tidyverse)

crashes = read_csv(
  file = "crashes_2014_2023.csv", 
  col_types = list(
    col_double(),    #  1) CASE_ID
    col_double(),    #  2) ACCIDENT_YEAR
    col_date(),      #  3) COLLISION_DATE 
    col_double(),    #  4) COLLISION_TIME 
    col_integer(),   #  5) DAY_OF_WEEK 
    col_character(), #  6) WEATHER_1 
    col_character(), #  7) WEATHER_2 
    col_character(), #  8) STATE_HWY_IND
    col_character(), #  9) COLLISION_SEVERITY 
    col_integer(),   # 10) NUMBER_KILLED 
    col_integer(),   # 11) NUMBER_INJURED 
    col_integer(),   # 12) PARTY_COUNT 
    col_character(), # 13) PCF_VIOL_CATEGORY 
    col_character(), # 14) TYPE_OF_COLLISION 
    col_character(), # 15) ROAD_SURFACE 
    col_character(), # 16) ROAD_COND_1 
    col_character(), # 17) ROAD_COND_2 
    col_character(), # 18) LIGHTING 
    col_character(), # 19) PEDESTRIAN_ACCIDENT 
    col_character(), # 20) BICYCLE_ACCIDENT 
    col_character(), # 21) MOTORCYCLE_ACCIDENT 
    col_character(), # 22) TRUCK_ACCIDENT 
    col_character(), # 23) NOT_PRIVATE_PROPERTY 
    col_character(), # 24) ALCOHOL_INVOLVED 
    col_character(), # 25) COUNTY 
    col_character(), # 26) CITY 
    col_double(),    # 27) POINT_X 
    col_double()     # 28) POINT_Y 
  ))


Comments
We should we derive other variables (may need to use "lubridate" package)

MONTH: extract month from COLLISION_DATE
HOUR: extract hour from COLLISION_TIME

title: 6) Mapping Crashes II
text:
In this module we continue visualizing maps of crashes in California.
# recommended packages
library(tidyverse)  # data wrangling and graphics
library(lubridate)  # for working with dates
library(sf)         # for working with geospatial vector-data
library(maps)       # has database of U.S. Counties
library(leaflet)    # web interactive maps

title: 6) Mapping Crashes II
text:
Choropleth Maps
We mainly consider web-interactive maps made with the "leaflet" package.
In particular, the idea is to create choropleth maps. One option is to color code based on proportions, and taken “region” into account (e.g. county, city, etc)

title: 6) Mapping Crashes II
text:
Map of California Counties
To plot the polygons of California counties, we need the corresponding polygon data set. The "maps" package has a "county" data (with polygons of U.S. counties) that can be converted to a simple features (“sf”) object via st_as_sf().
To graph polygons onto a leaflet map, we have to st_transform() the "sf" object to CRS = 4326 (coordinate reference system), otherwise leaflet will provide an annoying warning.

# polygons of California counties from "maps" package
# converted into an "sf" (simple features) object
us_counties_sf = st_as_sf(map("county", plot = FALSE, fill = TRUE)) 

# filtering counties in California
# transform to CRS = 4326 to prevent warning when using leaflet
cal_counties = us_counties_sf |> 
  st_transform(crs = 4326) |> 
  filter(str_detect(ID, "^california")) |> 
  mutate(county = str_remove(ID, "^california,"))

As a sanity check, we can plot maps with either "ggplot2" or "leaflet"

# sanity check: make sure map of CA is okay
ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = cal_counties)







# sanity check: make sure leaflet map is okay
cal_counties |> 
  leaflet() |> 
  addTiles() |> 
  addPolygons()

title: 6) Mapping Crashes II
9) Closeread Docs I
text:
In addition to using a Quarto Website for reporting and communication purposes, it would also be nice to utilize Closeread, a Quarto extension to create scrollytelling stories with HTML documents.
The official website of Closeread is:  https://closeread.dev
A companion website to learn Closeread is:  https://www.gastonsanchez.com/learn-closeread/

title: 9) Closeread Docs I
text:
Examples
Number of tropical cyclones in the North Atlantic, 1980-2022
https://www.gastonsanchez.com/learn-closeread/examples/example7


Mapping Storms in the North Atlantic, 1980-2022
https://www.gastonsanchez.com/learn-closeread/examples/example9

title: 9) Closeread Docs I
text:
Creating a Closeread Document
First contact with Closeread Docs

Introduction:  https://www.gastonsanchez.com/learn-closeread/modules/02-introduction.html

title: 10) Closeread Docs II
text:
In this module we continue our discussion around Closeread documents.
This time, we’ll focus on how to tell a story based on tropical cyclones, which involves using R code, some graphics, and going through the design process of a scrollytelling document.

title: Crashes in California
text:
This is the companion website to document and track carrying out a data analysis project on Crashes in California.
The main goal visualize and compare crash data across California using:

Summaries
Frequencies
